content.description:
pitch 1, good solid climbing to bolt and crux (5.11-) shortly after allows a non threatening swing. Continue to low angle/ledge area to belay. Escape to  Crab Corner is possible here.   

  Although you can do it as one pitch, I'd recommend belaying mid pitch to keep the leader on R from hitting the ground (as I was witness to). 

  pitch 2 !!!!! stiff climbing (5.10-/10) with VERY, very hard to place pro (I got FOUR brass nuts including two #2 HB offsets) before reaching the crummy bolt (1/4" Leeper as of 1997). This is a very traditional old school lead not for the faint of heart up open territory. I would advise leading the route in the shade over direct sun.
content.protection:
stoppers, cams to 3", and multiple brass nuts INCLUDING two #2 HB brass nuts at minimum.

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.
content.location: left of Rich and Dave route, 3rd route downhill from Mean Mistreater.

content.description: Fun jug haul start to more technical middle and fun finish.

This climb is located in the middle of the wall left of the climb Mean Mistreater.  The first bolt is up aways and may deter some.  The climbing then follows small crack systems and flakes right towards the ledge below a prominent chimney.  When we climbed it we found that it was easiest to traverse a bit further right at the end of pitch 1 and just belay at the three bolt anchor of Mean Mistreater.  The second pitch ascends the chimeny either in or out.  I found the crux of the route getting from the belay to in the chimney.  Belay at the top between a small boulder and a small oak.  Walk off.
content.protection:
There is one bolt about 15ft. up the beginning slab and the rest can be done with small to medium nuts and Camalots .3- #2

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.

content.description:
Mt. Lemmon in the early 1980s was full of potential for new routes.  For the most part, the ethic for first ascents was still from the ground up, but somewhat newly invented Fire rubber, RPs, and friends -- and a willingness to fall, sometimes a long way -- allowed us to be a little more aggressive than in years past.  The epitome of climbing, for a number of us locals of that era, was launching up a virgin face broken by incipient weaknesses, with little idea of the outcome, but faith that sooner or later some pro would appear -- and if not, at least some feature to drill from.  Pegasus, for me, was one of those climbs; it's perhaps my favorite FA at Windy Point.  And, yeah, I guess RR and I got carried away with the name. 

  From the belay ledge, trend left and up to the right end of a small roof, climb past two bolts, and gain a short finger crack above a bulge.  Superb and imaginative climbing clears the crack and gains easier, but spicy, face climbing that leads more or less directly to the top.   There's a great picture of Harrison Decker on the crux of Pegasus in Climbing No. 91 (taken by John Sherman, who did the 2nd ascent). 

  I'm told that you can link up Feelin' Fertile with Pegasus for an uberpitch of classic Lemmon face.  I'm talking trad, the real stuff, not like the weanie sport routes that now (2017) pollute the face.  ;)
content.protection: Two sets RPs, stoppers, double set of cams to 1.5 inches.
content.location: Pegasus climbs the steep face to the right of the 2nd pitch of Mean Mistreater, and to the left of the wide crack on Face It.  Approach by third classing up ledges to an adequate belay ledge (gear) down and right of the longish belay ledge atop the first pitch of Mean Mistreater.

content.description: This route is located in the middle of the Mean Mistreater formation. --Starts with a bolt up high and goes straight up face to a finger crack at top of P1 to chain anchors. --P2 head out right and then up to bolt 1 then back left to bolt 2. A fall at the crux could be a bad one because of the ledge. Tricky sequence on this crux so watch the fall. then up crack to short face and chain anchors. --This is an excellent climb in a beautiful setting. A true Mt. Lemmon classic. What a blast!!
content.protection:
mixed route(around 4 or 5 bolts).. 2 pitches with chain anchorsquickdraws, nuts, cams to #1 (including the tiny stuff)

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.

content.description: Great face climbing. This line is thin at the start and has a great middle section on nearly vertical rock. Hard to improve a climb that has a stemming move in the middle of the face. Chance encounter with some nice folks from Vegas lead to Katya and I doing the FA of this line I had set up earlier in the day. Turns out we both learned to climb at Taylors Falls on the St. Croix River in Minnesota, Thus the name.
content.location: Walking left (downhill) from the start of Mean Mistreater, the route is easily identifiable by a line of bolts with grey hangers.

content.description: Stout start trending diagonally left above a crack leads to the usual Windy Pt face paddling.
content.protection: Approx 7 bolts plus anchors w fixed steel biners - you can protect in the crack or stick clip the first bolt, both the climber and belayer would be in trouble if you fell before the first bolt
content.location: Pillar on the far right side and halfway up the Mean Mistreater formation - traverse in to the start on a wide ledge from flat area below the west face of Swim Fin

climbs.name: Irrational Inquirer
climbs.fa: Brad Smith (with roof start), 1985.   Steve Grossman, John Steiger, 1983

content.description: This climbs the face between the trad lines of Mean Mistreater and the Rich and Dave Route. (1) Scamper out a ledge leading left from near the base of Mean Mistreater, climb up a short right-facing dihedral, then move up and left to a bolt. Work back right and head up incipient cracks to a small roof system that can be somewhat skirted on the left to the Mean Mistreater ledge system.  Belay from gear on the ledge system, left of Mistreater's fixed belay station.  (2) Climb up the Rich and Dave Route crack for a short ways until possible to strike right, up face to a bolt underneath the long roof band protecting the final headwall left of Mean Mistreater. Turn the roof (crux), skirt another bulge on the left, then work up the headwall to the top.Originally, Steve led the second pitch ground up without bolts, but he avoided the crux roof by traversing out from the Rich and Dave Route above the roof, resulting in a stout 5.10 R.  Again from the ground up, Brad later did the FA of the crux roof, then did Steve's 5.10 R finish.  In 1990, apparently without consulting anyone from the FA, a party rap-bolted a line between Mean Mistreater and Irrational  Inquirer, naming it International Inquirer.  Unfortunately, the last few bolts of International  are on the line taken by Steve and Brad, thereby essentially eradicating the possibility of experiencing the upper part of the headwall as they and several others found it in the 80s.  There still may be some R-rated terrain lower down though, so I've kept the R rating in this post.
content.protection:
Standard Tucson trad rack (include micros).

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.
content.location: Find the base of Mean Mistreater. The route begins off the left end of the ledge to the left leading to a very obvious ten-foot tall right-facing dihedral.

content.description: Starts 1 pitch off the ground, at the P1 anchors of Mean Mistreater. Follow the bolt line that starts about 6 feet left and 10 feet up from the anchors.
content.protection: 7ish bolts. Bring small-medium gear for a few placements between bolts. Anchors at top. Walk off, or rap down Mean Mistreater.
content.location: This route starts 1 pitch off the ground, at the P1 anchors of Mean Mistreater and/or Feelin' Fertile.

content.description: Big holds lead to a short steep section to the final crux moves.
content.location: Just right of Sixy Lady. On the short lower section of the right side of the Mean Mistreater Wall.

content.description: This route is classic Mean Mistreater Wall face climbing on off vertical rock. Thoughtful movement with a definite crux and a finish that gets your attention. The rock is very good. Interestingly both of us were born in Germany.
content.protection: Bolts to Anchors of Mean Mistreater. Bring a light rack if you plan to finish on one of the upper pitches.
content.location: Mean Mistreater wall just right of the walls Namesake.

content.description:
The line starts with good holds over a shallow flake and then onto a section of thin slab. After clipping the 3rd bolt, you'll face a runout section of dicey slab to the next bolt. You may continue to a thin mantle shortly after the 3rd bolt; a fall above this point risks ground fall. Retreating above the 3rd bolt also means reversing the mantle. The climb finishes at the anchors for the start of the second pitch of Mean Mistreater. 

  I am unsure why the bolt was never placed, or if it has been removed since the first FA. Squeezing II shows the runout well on the Mean Mistreater Wall Topo. A good route to avoid unless you are very comfortable with thin slab moves.
content.protection: ~5 bolts, with runout between bolts #3 and #4. Double anchors for the rap/lower.
content.location: Bolt line starting to the right of Mean Mistreater.

content.description: from the base of mean mistreater we took the short 5.6 sixy lady to the base of the route which is a right facing corner right next to Beautiful flyaway, from the base start up the right facing corner, work the corner until you reach the wide crack... super fun, continue past the wide in prefect hands and then some face build an anchor and bring your buddy up walk off around the back  such a good climb!
content.protection: small to large wires and a rack up to 4, gear for anchor I used a 3, .5 and .4
content.location: far right of the formation on the shelf, the right facing corner to wide crack, you can walk up to it on the far right or climbing one of the two routes that will bring you to the base of it sixy lady or grace slick

content.description: From Steiger's guide--> The first 40 feet make the route: difficult climbing on superb rock, with a mandatory "Tucson runout".
content.protection: A bolt, then a light rack with stoppers. IIRC.
content.location: 1st route right of obvious dihedral of Crab Corner.

content.description: Hard start to a balancy move up and left. Fairly sustained at the grade.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors half way up the cliff.

content.description: Left of Crab Legs.  Chase the bolts placing additonal pro where you need it.
content.protection: 4 bolts plus standard rack.  Shares chain anchors with crab legs.

climbs.name: Crab Legs
climbs.fa: Scott McNamara, Brian Benedon, Peter Noebels (2000)

content.description:
At the top of the 4th class ramp, a #3 Camalot in a crack to the left will keep you from tumbling all the way down the hill...A possibly psychological nut placement right below the first bolt gets you up into position to clip it.. 

  You'll have to downclimb 2-3 feet on a 60m to get to the ground..
content.location:
To the left of Crab Corner and right of Crab Salad.  

  To me it seemed easiest to access the Mean Mistreater Wall by descending the gully where "Ego Donor" is (in between the Blazing Fin and the Swim Fin). The gully on the "Party Pooter" side (west side of the Swim Fin) is another option with some downclimbing.   At the bottom go right past the harder climbs to the corner near Faded Rock where the "Crab" climbs are.

content.description: Squeezing the Lemmon II has a good topo.  Look for a slightly less than vertical sloped open book with a crack right up the center.  Climb up the crack and bear right when it splits.  I seem to recall a bolt on the face to the right after the crack splits.
content.protection: small and medium cams and stoppers.  Plenty of good placements.

climbs.name: Beautiful Flyaway
climbs.fa: Steve Grossman, Fig, 1981.  Direct: Grossman, Steiger, April 2, 1983 .

content.description:
Another typical Grossman FA.  There are two starts, the original start, which traverses left onto the pinnacle's face from a ledge high on the right side of the crag, and the "direct" start, which begins on Face It but soon leaves the crack and diagonals right to underneath an obvious roof and a pin.  The original start gains the face above the roof from the right, whereas the direct start turns the roof.  Either way, a potential 20-foot fall exists off the crux, and a healthy 5.8 runout is necessary to reach the top.  The direct start boasts one of the most wild roof moves at Windy Point, worthy of the 3 stars given here (two stars for the original).  As an added bonus, Beautiful Flyaway (with the direct start) is one of the only routes ever to be pictured in the Tucson Citizen, the local newspaper (6" by 13", in color no less! (Nov. 14, 1985)). 

  By the way, rumor has it that the bolts on Jr. Gripper, installed in 1990, interfere with Beautiful Flyaway's head game.  If so, I suggest they be removed.
content.protection: Wired stoppers and cams to 2 inches.  I'm told that chains have been installed on top, but I'm not sure a 60m would be enough to reach the starting belay.
content.location: To the right of the Mean Mistreater is an obvious wide crack beginning well off the ground.  The wide crack is Face It (5.9; FA: Rich Thompson, Steve Grossman, 1976).  To the right of Face It is a somewhat freestanding pinnacle.  Beautiful Flyway essentially climbs the face of the pinnacle.

content.description: South facing crag with a mix of moderate to hard routes, both mixed and sport.  Best known for Mean Mistreater a 5.10 three star tucson classic, but there are lots of stars to be found here.  Great for winter climbing on moderate days.
